relation: Is the frequency busy? The frequency is busy. Please do not interfere.
Abbreviation for interference from other signals.
Abbreviation for interference from natural or human-made static.
Shall I increase power? Increase power.
Shall I decrease power? Decrease power.
Shall I send faster? Send faster (__words per minute [wpm]).
Shall I send more slowly? Send more slowly (__wpm).
Shall I stop sending or transmitting? Stop sending or transmitting.
Have you anything more for me? I have nothing more for you.
Are you ready? I am ready.
Did you receive and understand? Received and understood.
General call preceding a message addressed to all amateurs.
Change to transmission on another frequency (or to ___ kHz).
What is your location? My location is ____.
pageTitle: Common Ham Radio Q Signals - For Dummies
textBeforeTable: Hams use three-letter Q signals on every mode and even in face-to-face conversation. Here are the Q signals most commonly used in day-to-day operation. Each signal can be a question or an answer, as shown in the Meaning column. A complete list of ham radio Q signals, including those used on nets and repeaters, is available from AC6V. Part of the Ham Radio For Dummies Cheat Sheet H. Ward Silver By Common Ham Radio Q Signals } document.write('
